liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It wasn't just property prices and building approvals that have risen in recent months â ABS data shows new housing lending has risen too. In May, new housing lending jumped by 4.8%, which was much stronger than expectations, and follows a fall of 1% in April. Over the past year, new housing lending is down by 20.5% â but the Commonwealth Bank notes that turnaround in recent months has had a direct impact on house prices. Here's some of what they said in their note this afternoon: "The turnaround in lending the last three months has helped boost the recovery in home prices over the same time period. The RBA is watching this development closely, noting in the June Board Minutes "stabilisation in housing loan approvals suggested that financial conditions may not have been as tight as they had previously judged." "To the detail in May and the lift higher in home lending was driven by all three categories with owner occupier ex first home buyer (+3.5%), investor (+6.2%) and first home buyer (+5.5%) all rising. "First home buyers are likely responding to a number of forces. Rental shortages and rising rents are likely seeing first home buyers take the plunge and purchase. There are also a number of federal and state government programs in place to help this cohort enter the housing market. "Over the past year lending to first home buyers is down 15.1% compared to owner occupiers ex first home buyers (21.8%) and investors (20.9%). "External refinancing rose by a large 8.1% in May and was 22.4% higher compared to a year ago. The rapid increase in interest rates has led to a large number of mortgage holders seeking out a better deal and there are limited signs to show this is abating. "The fixed rate roll off currently underway will also be incentivising refinancing as borrowers look for lower variable rates to move to after their fixed rate expires." CBA also noted that ownerâoccupier refinancing reached a record high in May.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Jump in new housing lending boosts recovery in house prices

children.content: It wasn't just property prices and building approvals that have risen in recent months â ABS data shows new housing lending has risen too.
In May, new housing lending jumped by 4.8%, which was much stronger than expectations, and follows a fall of 1% in April.
Over the past year, new housing lending is down by 20.5% â but the Commonwealth Bank notes that turnaround in recent months has had a direct impact on house prices.
Here's some of what they said in their note this afternoon:
"The turnaround in lending the last three months has helped boost the recovery in home prices over the same time period. The RBA is watching this development closely, noting in the June Board Minutes
"stabilisation in housing loan approvals suggested that financial conditions may not have been as tight as they had previously judged."
"To the detail in May and the lift higher in home lending was driven by all three categories with owner occupier ex first home buyer (+3.5%), investor (+6.2%) and first home buyer (+5.5%) all rising.

"First home buyers are likely responding to a number of forces. Rental shortages and rising rents are likely seeing first home buyers take the plunge and purchase. There are also a number of federal and state government programs in place to help this cohort enter the housing market.
"Over the past year lending to first home buyers is down 15.1% compared to owner occupiers ex first home buyers (21.8%) and investors (20.9%).

"External refinancing rose by a large 8.1% in May and was 22.4% higher compared to a year ago. The rapid increase in interest rates has led to a large number of mortgage holders seeking out a better deal and there are limited signs to show this is abating.
"The fixed rate roll off currently underway will also be incentivising refinancing as borrowers look for lower variable rates to move to after their fixed rate expires."
CBA also noted that ownerâoccupier refinancing reached a record high in May.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Commonwealth Bank has just released some analysis off the back of the new housing lending and building approvals data, saying the "strong" pieces of housing data will be factored into the RBA's cash rate decision tomorrow. CBA is the only one of the big four banks to expect the RBA to pause its current rate hiking cycle, saying it expects the "cash rate to stay on hold in a line ball decision". "The deceleration in the monthly CPI should be enough for the RBA to pause its hiking cycle," the note read. "Although today's stronger housing related data could, together with a tight labour market and lingering inflation concerns, tip the decision the other way." CBA instead expects a rate hike in August, after a pause in July's meeting.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Deceleration' in monthly CPI should be enough for interest rate pause, CBA says

children.content: Commonwealth Bank has just released some analysis off the back of the new housing lending and building approvals data, saying the "strong" pieces of housing data will be factored into the RBA's cash rate decision tomorrow.
CBA is the only one of the big four banks to expect the RBA to pause its current rate hiking cycle, saying it expects the "cash rate to stay on hold in a line ball decision".
"The deceleration in the monthly CPI should be enough for the RBA to pause its hiking cycle," the note read.
"Although today's stronger housing related data could, together with a tight labour market and lingering inflation concerns, tip the decision the other way."
CBA instead expects a rate hike in August, after a pause in July's meeting.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you missed it over the weekend, Apple has become the first public company to surpass a $US3 trillion ($4.5 trillion) market value on Friday (US time). Shares in the tech giant closed up at 2.3% on Friday to be worth $US193.97, making its market value a mammoth $3.04 trillion. It follows substantial surges for tech companies on the market this year, with Microsoft and Nvidia also recording strong gains. You can read more about Apple's surging market value below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ICYMI: Apple becomes the first company to close at $US3 trillion market value

featuredLink.title: Apple becomes first public company to close at $US3 trillion market value

children.content: If you missed it over the weekend, Apple has become the first public company to surpass a $US3 trillion ($4.5 trillion) market value on Friday (US time).
Shares in the tech giant closed up at 2.3% on Friday to be worth $US193.97, making its market value a mammoth $3.04 trillion.
It follows substantial surges for tech companies on the market this year, with Microsoft and Nvidia also recording strong gains.
You can read more about Apple's surging market value below:
